descriptionSet.description: In this poster, published by Kedar Nath Arya five famous Hindu warriors can be seen- Shivaji, Guru Gobind, Maharana Pratap, Maharaja Chhatar Sal and Vir Banda Baragi. In the centre Maharana Pratap, the ruler of Mewar (Northwest India) can be seen on a horse whose rear feet are planted on a map of India. In the background, a Hindu temple can be seen.

inscription.text: Chhatar Pati Shiva Ji Guru Gobind Singh Ji
Maharaja Chhatar Sal Maharana Partap on Horse. Vir Banda Baragi
Published by :- Kedar Nath Arya, Throh Distt Sialkot.
Copy Right Strictly Reserved. By the Publisher :- Sole Agents :- Ganesh Dass Dwarka Nath, Machhi Hatta, Lahore.
Approved by All India Hindu Leaders.
।। अखंड भारत अमर रहे ।। राष्ट्र के पांच रत्न

hra:item.hra:value: आर्यन [Aryan]

text-hi: जय जननी
text-hi: [आर्य्यन] [not clear]

description-en: In this poster, published by Kedar Nath Arya five famous Hindu warriors can be seen- Shivaji, Guru Gobind, Maharana Pratap, Maharaja Chhatar Sal and Vir Banda Baragi. In the centre Maharana Pratap, the ruler of Mewar (Northwest India) can be seen on a horse whose rear feet are planted on a map of India. In the background, a Hindu temple can be seen. (sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The name in the title Maharana Partap is a local variation of the more commonly used spelling "Maharana Pratap". (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The central protagonist of this bi-lingual print, the work of the artist “Aryan” (whose name is inscribed in Devanagari on the globe), is the figure of the sixteenth-century Rajput ruler Maharana Rana Pratap; he rides his famous steed (known to many school children in India as Chetak) whose two legs are placed on a partially visible map of India (left un-named) inscribed on a partly visible globe. Surrounding this central figure are other heroes “approved by All India Hindu Leaders”—“Chhatar Pati Shiva Ji,” “Sikh Gobind Singh,” “Vir Banda Ba[i]ragi,” and “Maharaja Chhatar Lal”—all of whom had distinguished themselves by opposing Mughal or Muslim dominance in the subcontinent, protected the Hindu faith (hence the temple in the background), and saved “the mother” (janani). They are thus declared to be “the five gems of the nation.” At the top of the print, the phrase “May Undivided India [akhand Bharat] Be Eternal” suggests that talk of Partition was already in the air, possibly dating this print to the late 1930s-1940s. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)
related literature: Coplan, Ian, 1997. The Princes of India in the Endgame of Empire, 1917-1947. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp. 229-287. (gs)

related literature: Ramaswamy, Sumathi 2011. "Artful Mapping in Bazaar India. Cartographic Reflections on the Priya Paul Collection". http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/116/index_1.html last accessed 2011-04-06 (gs)
related literature: Ramusack, Barbara, 2003. The Indian Princes and their States. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp. 245-274. (gs)
related literature: Thongchai Winichakul. 1996. Maps and the Formation of the Geo-Body of Siam. In Asian Forms of the Nation, edited by H. Antlov and S. Tonnesson. London: Curzon Press, p. 70. (gs)
